The Master said: *"Without taboos."*
The Master said: *"The seventy-ninth chapter: ‘In reconciling great resentment, there must remain residual resentment—how can this be called good?’ How do you explain this?"*
Wei’an said: *"Restraining oneself is good."*
Ding’an said: *"Restraining oneself and returning to propriety."*
He’an said: *"Compassion and forbearance are good."*
The Master said: *"All have grasped the point."*
Someone asked: *"Master, what do you say?"*
The Master said: *"Forgetting both kindness and resentment."*

The Master said: *"The eightieth chapter’s final line states: ‘The people, even to old age and death, do not visit one another.’ How do you explain this?"*
He’an said: *"Abiding in their homes."*
Ding’an said: *"Without contention."*
The Master said: *"The inner realm does not extend outward; the outer realm does not enter in."*

The Master said: *"The eighty-first chapter: ‘The Dao of the sage is to act without contending.’ What is ‘without contending’?"*
None answered appropriately.
The Master said: *"Lay the temple’s banner pole flat."*

The Master then said: *"Each of you compose a couplet embodying the two characters ‘Dao’ and ‘virtue.’"*
He’an said:
*"The Dao stores all functions;
Virtue manifests in all benevolence."*

Ding’an said:
*"The Dao does not lie in cultivation;
Virtue does not lie in seeking."*

Wei’an said:
*"The Dao is not non-existence within non-existence;
Virtue is not existence within existence."*

Shi’an said:
*"The Dao that can be spoken is not the Dao;
The highest virtue does not act as virtue."*

The Master said:

chunks.translated_text:
**The Recorded Sayings of Master Qing’an Yingchan, Volume Three**
*Compiled by Zhitang Shi’an and Miao Shanshi*

**Entering the Gate of Zhonghe Hermitage**
A silver mountain, an iron wall—
by whom was this built?
Pass through this barrier,
and there is no opening nor closing.

How then to break through this barrier?
The Master struck the ground with his staff and said:
*"Hmph! Enter the Hall of the Sages here."*

No sooner is the Golden Portal spoken of as a transformed body
than the celestial mechanism is already revealed,
and the adornment of external appearances
becomes but another scene of defeat.

What then is to be done?
*"Bah! To behold the golden full-moon visage,
all must step forward together."*

**On the Sage**
The Sage is most compassionate, most benevolent, most numinous, most holy,
holding the gate of life and death,
enacting execution and issuing decrees,
stirring the turbid and lifting the pure,
driving out evil and aiding the upright.
Evil goes unpunished; good meets no response.

Yet such vast spiritual power is manifest.
If one begs for life from the hands of Qing’an,
having already received it—what then is there to bow for?
*"Hmph! Because I receive reverence, who dares not show respect?"*

**Winter Solstice Ascending the Hall to Expound the Scriptures**
After ascending the seat, offering incense, and reciting the invocations,
the Master raised his staff and said:
*"The Dao is originally wordless;
I too have little to say.
But with this staff,
sometimes it is the substance in my hand,
sometimes it is the function in my hand."*

He held the staff horizontally and asked:
*"Is this substance or function?"*
After a long pause, he continued:
*"In function, it props up heaven and supports earth."*

This staff possesses unfathomable spiritual power,
its wondrous uses beyond measure.
The moment it is raised,
the boundless flying heavenly deities, the Immortal Kings of the Ten Directions,
and the countless hosts of the Great Longevity Spirits
all stand in submission.
Even the Most High Lord Lao comes to the tip of the staff to beg for life.

Why? *"Once the authority is in hand, the command is issued."*

He raised the staff and said:
*"Behold, all of you!"*
He struck once and said:
*"Strike once—strike the void into □ leaps!"*
He stirred it once and said:
*"Stir once—stir the primordial chaos into dense fusion!"*
He drew a line and said:
*"Draw once—draw open the fences of the Three Teachings!"*
He tapped once and said:
*"Tap once—tap through the nostrils of all!"*

Though it possesses such vast spiritual power,
not a single one in the entire world has it ever struck.
Why?

The Pure Hermitage’s staff strikes not the dullard.
With a shout, he asks:
*"Is there anyone who wishes to taste the rod’s bite? Step forth then."*
The True Hermitage emerges, bows, and asks:
*"When snow falls at the Winter Solstice, what is its meaning?"*
The Master replies:
*"This question drips water that freezes solid—
it cannot be taken as an auspicious sign,
yet it cannot be dismissed as inauspicious.
Without the root of learning’s heel, it is no propitious omen.
Without the eye of accumulated study, how then to see it?"*
Hmph!
*"The earth’s thunder shakes as the solitary yang arrives,
the White Maiden and Azure Lad meet in the Crimson Palace.
The song ends, the wine runs dry, clouds and rain disperse—
shattered jade scatters wildly across the void.
Is this not the snow of the Winter Solstice month?"*
Hmph! *"Do not mistake it for mere scenery."*
Why?
*"No need to seek the Winter Solstice beyond the city walls—
within the body, a single bowel stirs to life.
In the year, there is the year’s Winter Solstice;
in the month, the month’s Winter Solstice;
in the day, the day’s Winter Solstice;
in the hour, the hour’s Winter Solstice.
The Festival of the Solitary Yang is the year’s Winter Solstice;
the first day of each month is the month’s Winter Solstice;
the midnight hour is the day’s Winter Solstice.
Now tell me—what is the Winter Solstice within the body?"*
The True Hermitage says:
*"Pray, Master, grant instruction."*
The Master replies:
*"When the moon reaches the heart of the sky,
when the wind brushes the water’s surface—
both hold the same pure savor,
yet few indeed are those who know it."*

Do you understand?
The disciple replies: "Yes."
The Master says: "Yet I fear there may still be those who do not fully grasp it—recite again the chapter *To the Utmost Void*?"
The disciple replies: "I can recite it."
The Master says: "First, recite the opening four lines."
The disciple recites:
*"To the utmost void, hold fast to stillness;
the myriad things arise together,
I thereby observe their return."*

The Master says: "Confucius said: *'Thunder lies within the earth—Return. The former kings, on this solstice day, closed the passes, forbade merchants and travelers from moving, and the lords did not inspect their domains.'* This refers to the ancient sage-kings who, on the Winter Solstice, closed the gates, halted all commerce and travel, and bade the people attain emptiness and preserve stillness, awaiting the return of the new yang. Once the new yang returns, the four seasons proceed in order, and the five grains flourish. When people, at the time of the yang’s return, maintain tranquility—keeping the inner realm from leaking outward and the outer realm from intruding inward—they await the yang’s return. Once the yang returns, the four elements are at peace, the hundred bones are in harmony—this is the Way of long life and enduring vision.

Now, today is the Winter Solstice with snowfall; merchants and travelers naturally cease their journeys—how could this not be an auspicious sign? Yet though all manner of auspicious signs may appear, none compare to the absence of *you*."

"Recite the next four lines."
The disciple recites:
*"Now, the teeming things,
each returns to its root.
Returning to the root is called stillness;
stillness is called the restoration of life."*

The Master says: "These four lines speak of observing transformation and knowing return. Consider the hexagram *Return*: from *Kun* it returns—*Kun* is stillness, yang is movement. Stillness at its extreme gives rise to movement, and the Heart of Heaven is revealed."

"Recite the next four lines."
The disciple recites:
*"Restoration of life is called constancy;
to know constancy is called illumination.
Not knowing constancy, reckless action brings misfortune."*

The Master says: "If one comprehends these subtle workings, one directly enters the realm of true constancy—hence, it is called illumination. But if, when the yang returns, one remains ignorant and acts recklessly, one will surely lose one’s life—hence, it is called misfortune."

"Recite the next four lines."
The disciple recites:
*"To know constancy is to be all-embracing;
all-embracing is to be impartial;
impartial is to be kingly;
kingly is to be heavenly."*

The Master says: "*All-embracing* means to broadly receive and contain. *Impartial* means to extend universally to all things. When one is utterly impartial and universal, one may become a ruler, a teacher—Heaven and humanity share the same principle."

"Recite the final lines."
The disciple recites:
*"Heavenly is the Dao;
the Dao is enduring.
To the end of one’s days, one does not perish."*

The Master says: "To embody Heaven and unite with the Dao—this is the fullness of the Way of long life and enduring vision. Advancing further from here, one realizes the wondrous truth of the *non-arising dharma patience*. If one recognizes this intimately and directly assumes it, settling into the work of stillness—attaining the utmost void, holding fast to stillness—the Heart of Heaven is revealed. Once the Heart of Heaven is revealed, one radiates great luminosity in that very place, illuminating the three thousand great thousandfold worlds. Within each of these worlds are three thousand great thousandfold lands; within each land, three thousand great thousandfold Dharma gates; within each gate, three thousand great thousandfold wise and virtuous beings; within each being, three thousand great thousandfold retinues; within each retinue, eyes that see the same Heart of Heaven, each radiating the same light, illuminating the three thousand great thousandfold worlds. In this way, all beings on earth breathe through a single nostril.

Only then does one realize that every month, every day, every moment is the Winter Solstice—today’s Winter Solstice is but an ordinary day. An ancient worthy said: *'It is all just an ordinary day—yet the deluded masses stir up a commotion.'* Since it is merely an ordinary day, why do we perform these rituals today? Is it something extraordinary? Though we must follow local customs and add a footnote as convention requires—does anyone understand this footnote?"

Shi’an says: "I do not."
The Master says: "Ask me, then."
The disciple asks: "What is the footnote for the Winter Solstice?"
The Master replies: *"On this mid-winter day, joyous snowfall—may your honored presence be blessed with boundless fortune in all your movements."*
"Do you understand?"
The disciple replies: "Yes."

He taps it once: "Listen—does it have ears or not?"

chunks.original_text: 若有人参得着，便从法座上，拖下李清庵来，一顿打死，深掘坑厚着土埋，教不见踪迹，不为过。 若参不着，却被李清庵埋却你去也。 其或未然，我更添个注脚。 颂曰： 我有一件物，能小亦能大。 体则同太虚，用则遍法界。 拈起天不容，放下地莫载。 见之者则突出眼睛，闻之者则迸裂脑盖。 道人会此振动篷岛三山，缁流会此掌握曹溪一派。 以之治国国安民丰，以之助道时清道泰。 若论酬价价直万两黄金，若遇知音不用一文便卖。 为甚不用一文，不图利只图快。 只今举似，向君试问：会也不会？ 实庵曰：不会。 师曰：休论会与不会，只今自买自卖。 打圆象，云：看两手缝合中间，拈出自然香。 太上老君圣诞上堂 师升座云：太上元无上，常存日用间。 可怜无学辈，刚道出幽关。 大众且道：太上在甚么处？ 咦，只今见在说法，诸人还会么？ 纵饶直下会意，犹隔清庵一线道在。 何以故？ 若言他是太上，自己却是甚么？ 须是向自己究竟，方见得亲切。 太上云； 真常之道，悟者自得。 即此意也。 又云：众生所以不得真道者，为有妄心。 是谓妄心一动，起种种差别因缘，因缘缠缚，失道之本也。 圣人为见众生迷真之故，於是设立种种方便，诱谕世人离诸染着，出诸迷径，是经所以作也。 经也者，返道之径欤。 读是经者，当知此经元是强名，本无可说，说亦不得。 取不得，舍不得，添不得，减不得，形容不得，举似人不得。 不属讲论，不属智识，不属见闻，不属有无。 莫作实相会，莫作实虚无会，莫作文理会，莫作断常会。 然则从事於道者，将奚所自耶？ 非执大象者，则不足造也。 太上云：执大象，天下往，往而不害，安平太； 乐与饵，过客止，道之出口，淡乎其无味。 是谓以声色见道者，属无常法，终有尽期。 道之出口，淡而无味，视之不足见，听之不足闻，用之不可既。 大哉，圣人之言乎。 若是个信得及底，便能离一切相，了一切法，直下打并，教赤洒洒、空荡荡地，潜大音於希声，隐大象於无形，则自然形神俱妙，与道合真也。 奈何今之学者，不求师旨，私意揣度，或泥於文理，或执着文辞，圣人作经之义，由是晦矣。 此经中不注脚者，往往不同，良由此也。 殊不知才开臭口，十万八千。 才言可道，便非常道。 才言可名，便非常名。 然则常道不可道，五千余言非道乎？ 常名不可名，道德经名非名乎？ 咦，非道不可道，不可道即道。 非名不可名，不可名即名。 若向这裹具眼，参学事毕。 其或未然，未兔随人脚转，仁者以仁见，智者以智见，百姓日用而不知。 故圣人之道，知之者鲜矣。 清庵不惜两片，为你诸人道破。 此一卷经，拭不净底故纸，既是不净故纸，无用五千余言发明，不可道之义也。 譬如大医治病，对证发药，病既瘥矣，药亦无用。 既得常道，五千余言亦无用。 作是见者，则知可道可名，道之边徼也； 不可道、不可名，道之玄妙也。 有名之徼，道之用也； 无名之妙，道之体也。 无名，天地之始也； 有名，万物之母也。 此两者同出而异名，同谓之玄，玄之又玄，众妙之门。 苟有自有名之徼而造无名之妙者，真常之道得矣。 非天下之至虚，其孰能与於此。 大众，清庵饶舌至此，是说耶、非说耶？
chunks.translated_text:
If one among you penetrates this, then drag Li Qing’an down from the dharma seat, beat him to death, dig a deep pit, and bury him thick with earth—let no trace remain—it would not be excessive. If you fail to penetrate it, then Li Qing’an will bury you instead. Should this still not suffice, I shall add another annotation.

A verse says:
I have a single thing—
It can be small, it can be vast.
In essence, it is one with the great void;
In function, it pervades the dharma realm.
Lift it, and heaven cannot contain it;
Set it down, and earth cannot bear it.
Those who see it startle with bulging eyes;
Those who hear it split their skulls asunder.
If a Daoist grasps this, the three mountains of Peng Island tremble;
If a black-robed monk grasps this, the lineage of Cao Stream is held in hand.
With it, govern the state—state is at peace, people prosper;
With it, aid the Dao—times are clear, the Dao flourishes.
Were one to speak of its value, its worth would be ten thousand taels of gold;
Yet if one meets a true connoisseur, it is sold without a single coin.
Why without a single coin?
Not for profit—only for joy.
Now I raise it before you and ask:
Do you understand, or do you not?

Shi’an says: I do not.

The Master says: Never mind understanding or not—today, you buy and sell it yourself.

He molds a round image and says: Look—within the seam of these two hands, plucked forth, it is naturally fragrant.

**On the Birthday of the Supreme Lord Lao, Ascending the Seat**

The Master ascends the seat and says: The Supreme is without peer, yet abides in daily use. Pity those without learning, who merely speak of emerging from the hidden pass. Now, all of you, tell me: Where does the Supreme reside?

Hmph! Even now, as he speaks the dharma, do any of you understand? Even if you grasp the meaning at once, you remain a thread’s breadth from Qing’an’s Way. Why? If you say *he* is the Supreme, then what are *you*? You must investigate within yourself to see it intimately.

The Supreme says:
The true and constant Dao—those who awaken attain it.
This is the meaning.

Again, he says: The reason beings do not attain the true Dao is because of deluded mind. When the deluded mind stirs, it gives rise to all manner of karmic conditions. Bound by these conditions, they lose the root of the Dao. Seeing that beings are lost in delusion, the sage establishes various expedient means to guide the world, detaching them from defilements and leading them out of deluded paths—this is why the scripture is composed. The scripture is the path that returns to the Dao.

Those who read this scripture should know: this scripture is but a forced name. In truth, there is nothing to be said, and even if said, it cannot be said. It cannot be grasped, cannot be abandoned, cannot be added to, cannot be diminished, cannot be described, cannot be conveyed to others. It does not belong to discourse, to knowledge, to perception, to hearing, to being or non-being. Do not take it as the mark of reality, do not take it as true emptiness, do not take it as literary meaning, do not take it as annihilation or permanence.

Then how should one who engages with the Dao proceed? Only those who grasp the great image can attain it.

The Supreme says: Grasp the great image, and all under heaven will come. Coming without harm, they rest in great peace. Music and bait may halt the passing traveler, but the Dao, when spoken, is bland and without flavor. Those who perceive the Dao through sound and form cling to impermanent dharmas, which ultimately come to an end. The Dao, when spoken, is bland and flavorless—seen, it is not enough to behold; heard, it is not enough to listen to; used, it cannot be exhausted.

Great indeed are the words of the sage! If one truly trusts this, one can leave behind all marks, end all dharmas, and directly merge them into a single whole—utterly bare, utterly empty—concealing the great sound in silence, hiding the great image in formlessness. Then, naturally, form and spirit are both wondrous, and one unites with the Dao in truth.

Yet how is it that today’s scholars do not seek the master’s intent, but privately speculate, some clinging to literary meaning, others fixating on words? The sage’s purpose in composing the scripture is thus obscured. The unannotated passages in this scripture often differ—this is the reason. Little do they know that the moment one opens one’s foul mouth, ten thousand eight thousand errors arise. The moment one says “the Dao that can be spoken,” it is not the constant Dao. The moment one says “the name that can be named,” it is not the constant name.

Then is the constant Dao unspeakable? Are the five thousand words not the Dao? Is the constant name unnameable? Is the *Daodejing* not a name?

Hmph! The Dao that cannot be spoken—*that* is the Dao. The name that cannot be named—*that* is the name. If you have the eye to see this, your study of the Dao is complete. If not, you merely follow others’ footsteps: the benevolent see it as benevolence, the wise see it as wisdom, the common people use it daily yet do not know it. Thus, few understand the sage’s Dao.

Qing’an spares not his two lips to reveal this to you all. This scroll of scripture is but soiled paper, unfit for wiping. Since it is soiled paper, the five thousand words cannot elucidate the meaning of the unspeakable Dao. It is like a great physician treating illness—prescribing medicine according to the ailment. Once the illness is cured, the medicine is no longer needed. Once the constant Dao is attained, the five thousand words are also useless.

Those who see it thus know: the speakable and nameable are the fringes of the Dao; the unspeakable and unnameable are the Dao’s profound mystery. The named fringe is the Dao’s function; the nameless mystery is the Dao’s essence. The nameless is the beginning of heaven and earth; the named is the mother of the ten thousand things. These two emerge together yet bear different names—together they are called the profound. Profound beyond profound—they are the gate of all wonders.

If one can proceed from the named fringe to the nameless mystery, the true and constant Dao is attained. Who but the most utterly empty under heaven could achieve this?

All of you—Qing’an has spoken at length thus far. Is this speaking, or is it not speaking?

chunks.original_text: 诸人闻经至此，是闻耶、非闻耶？ 善智识，苟有不闻而闻者，方会清庵无说之说。 恁么则圣人作经之意明矣。 起初一句，至矣尽矣，休更疑惑。 或白：道既不可道，名既不可名，今日大作法事，莫非多事乎？ 曰：不然。 太上二月十五日降诞，非真也，显生生之义也。 予今与太上庆诞，正欲发明起初一句也。 何多事之有，复何疑哉？ 大众，起初一句已自说了，末后一句又作么生？ 咦，父母所生口，终不为吾通。 下座放参。 师曰：视之不见名曰希，听之不闻名曰夷，搏之不得名曰微，此三者不可致诘。 予谓视之不见名曰希，莫非无色乎； 听之不闻名曰夷，莫非无声乎； 搏之不得名曰微，莫非无形乎。 举拂子云：见么？ 敲一敲云：闻么？ 若作见闻会，未具参学眼； 不作见闻会，亦未具参学眼。 诸人作么会？ 嘿庵出云：见色非干色，闻声不是声，色身无碍处，亲到法王城。 师曰：离却语言。 嘿庵坚起拳头云：看。 打一拳云：听。 这个还属见闻也无？ 师曰：敲空作响。 嘿庵曰：更有么？ 师曰：待汝隐大象於无形，潜大音於希声，却来相见。 嘿庵曰：唯，拜谢而退。 师举拄杖云：泥牛喘月，木马嘶风，观之似有觅无踪。 清庵拄杖子，画倒妙高峰。 又道：开口即错，可劳举似。 咦，若向拄杖下当虚皇的意，未梦见在。 何以故？ 善行无辙述、善言无瑕谪，善计不用筹策，善闭无关键而不可开，善结无绳约而不可解。 颂曰：举步不在脚，把物非干手。 摸着鼻孔尖，通身都是口。 若能於此善参详，七七元来四十九。 若向这裹会得，方知道太上说是经不曾开口，清庵举拄杖不曾动手。 其或未然，且向声色裹做工夫，还有会底么？ 不得开口，不得动手，离却声色，出来相见。 道得也吃棒，道不得也吃棒。 黄居士出，方欲开勾，侍者云：不得开口。 良久，踏一踏。 师云：更有在。
chunks.translated_text:
All of you who have heard the scripture thus far—is this hearing, or is it not hearing? Those of keen wisdom and insight, if there are those who hear what is not heard, only then do they meet Qing’an’s "speaking of no-speaking." In this way, the Sage’s intent in composing the scripture becomes clear. The opening phrase—it is perfect, complete; cease all doubt.

Someone asks: If the Dao cannot be spoken, and names cannot be named, then why today’s grand ritual—is this not superfluous? The master replies: Not so. The Supreme’s descent on the fifteenth day of the second month is not real—it reveals the meaning of ceaseless generation. Today, celebrating the Supreme’s birth is precisely to illuminate that opening phrase. What superfluity is there? What doubt remains?

All of you—the opening phrase has already spoken itself. What then of the closing phrase? Hmph! The mouth given by father and mother will never serve me.

The master descends from the seat and dismisses the assembly.

The master says: "Seen yet unseen—called *xī*; heard yet unheard—called *yí*; grasped yet unobtainable—called *wēi*. These three cannot be interrogated." I say: Seen yet unseen—called *xī*—is this not formless? Heard yet unheard—called *yí*—is this not soundless? Grasped yet unobtainable—called *wēi*—is this not shapeless?

He raises his whisk and asks: Do you see? He taps it once and asks: Do you hear? If you take this as seeing and hearing, your eye of study is not yet sharp. If you do not take this as seeing and hearing, your eye of study is still not sharp. How do all of you understand this?

Hey An steps forward and says:
Seeing form is not form,
Hearing sound is not sound.
Where the colored body is unobstructed,
One arrives at the city of the Dharma King.

The master says: Leave behind words.
Hey An clenches his fist and says: Look.
He strikes once and says: Listen.
Does this still belong to seeing and hearing?

The master says: Striking emptiness to make a sound.
Hey An asks: Is there more?
The master replies: When you hide the great elephant in formlessness, and conceal the great sound in soundlessness, then come to meet me.

Hey An says: Yes. He bows in gratitude and retreats.

The master raises his staff and says:
The mud ox pants at the moon,
The wooden horse neighs in the wind—
Gazing, it seems to exist, yet no trace is found.
Qing’an’s staff draws the inverted Wondrous Peak.

He continues: To open the mouth is already a mistake—how laborious to raise such things! Hmph! If you seek the August Emperor’s intent beneath the staff, you have not even dreamed of it. Why? The good walker leaves no tracks; the good speaker leaves no flaws; the good reckoner needs no counting rods; the good closer needs no bolts yet cannot be opened; the good binder needs no cords yet cannot be untied.

The ode says:
The step does not depend on the foot,
Grasping things does not depend on the hand.
Touch the tip of the nose—
The whole body is a mouth.

If you can thoroughly investigate this,
The forty-nine days were originally seven sevens.
If you understand it here,
You will know the Supreme spoke the scripture without ever opening his mouth,
And Qing’an raised his staff without ever moving his hand.
If you have not yet done so,
Then work within sound and form—
Is there anyone who understands?
You may not open your mouth,
You may not move your hand.
Leave behind sound and form—
Come forward and meet me.

If you speak, you receive the staff.
If you do not speak, you still receive the staff.

Huang the Layman steps forward, about to open the register, when the attendant says: You may not open your mouth. After a long silence, he stamps his foot once.
The master says: There is more.

chunks.original_text: 黄咳嗽。 师曰：早迟八刻。 定庵出拜云：请师再举。 师曰：不得开口。 定庵竖拳。 又曰：不得动手。 定庵喝。 师曰：向上更有在。 定庵曰：更有个甚么？ 师曰：只今座下人众，好向静处理会。 师下座，定庵随行，师把住云：那裹去？ 定庵一不．无处去。 师云：恁么去，且免吃棒。 定庵拜谢。 清庵茔蟾子语录卷之三竟 #1此句之前疑有缺文。 清庵莹蟾子语录卷之四 门弟子宁庵邓德成编 维扬作句 师在维扬作他句，令门人续一句。 师曰：若有合辙者，许进一步。 师曰：无形无影亦无名，撑柱乾坤古到今。 刚被清庵掀倒了，定庵曰：大千沙界总成金。 无庵曰：杳无踪迹绝迫寻。 复庵曰：要知下手定中寻。 嘿庵曰：变成大地作黄金。 月庵曰：虚无粉碎没踪寻。 师曰：除无庵外，一状领过。 帅曰：乾鼎金炉烹日月，天罡斗柄斡璇玑。 劈开混沌金丹就，定庵曰：进出圆光遍界辉。 无庵曰：抱个婴儿谒紫微。 昔庵曰：直谒丹霄不用梯。 复庵曰：服了乘鸾造太微。 嘿庵曰：认得中间一点辉。 素庵曰：放出光明太始归。 师曰：谛观诸子之作，皆且且，独嘿庵曰较些子。 师曰：举步踏翻无色，抬头撞倒大罗天。 有人问我安身处，定庵曰：透出金测无碍圈。 无庵曰：一颗中纳大千。 复庵曰：隐在鸿蒙沫判前。 嘿库曰：无减无增本自然。 月俺曰：只在眉毛眼睫前。 师曰：定庵为上，复庵次之。 师曰：历劫元来一宝珠，硬如生铁软如酥。 大千沙界无安处，定庵曰：包尽乾坤造化模。 无庵曰：道外虚无尽不敷。 复庵曰：照彻虚空一也无。 普庵曰：看见分明觅后无。 嘿庵曰：遍满虚空总是渠。 爱山曰：无限清光照太虚。 师曰：都未尽，在其间，独定庵、嘿庵较些子。 师曰：着无着有总非功，两下俱捐又落空。 无有兼资终不一，定庵曰：无中真有始潜通。 嘿庵曰： 非无非有始圆通。 无庵曰：非无非有显神通。 复庵曰：太虚同体道方通。 师曰：都较些子。 予则曰：不如默默守其中。 师曰：圆陀陀地一围圈产在鸿蒙未判前。 没蒂没根无可把定庵曰：方明此际是真筌。 嘿庵曰：现前 应用十分全。 无庵曰：要知月落不离天。 复庵曰：寂然不动悟真诠。 帅曰：嘿庵一句可取。 师曰：上柱天兮下柱地，中间一窍不通气。 视之不见听无声，定庵曰：吃饭着衣常不昧。 嘿庵曰：应用头头皆不离。 无庵曰：拍塞虚空神鬼畏。 损庵曰：却与虚空有何异。 师曰：定庵可取。 师又曰：立鼎烧乾四大海，安炉炼碎五须弥。 金丹成象包三界，定庵曰：方显男兄得志时。 无庵曰：道本无为喻有为。 嘿庵曰：此是先天先地时。 济庵曰：正是超凡入圣时。 师曰：定庵一句为绝。 师在昭阳四圣道院，与诸法眷炼志，今并附于此。 师曰：笔锋一蘸江湖竭、墨梃才磨大地穿。 拍塞虚空书一画，嘿庵曰：亘今亘古蔼云烟。 息庵曰：毫尖露出本来天。 退庵曰：画开父母未生前。 静庵曰：此玄玄外更无玄。 师曰：静庵、退庵较些子。 退庵一句，改作混沌未分前更妙。 师曰：小小庵兄小小蟾，潜藏不许外人瞻，夜来开放吞天口，嘿庵曰：满腹丹砂火正炎。 静庵曰：嚼碎方知苦与甜。 退庵曰：大地山河舌下潜。 一庵曰：一味醍醐别样甜。 师曰：都较些子。 予则曰：吞尽乾坤尚不厌。

*Compiled by disciple Ning’an Deng Decheng*
*Composed in Weiyang*

The master was in Weiyang composing a line, instructing his disciples to continue with another.
The master says: If any match the rhythm, they may advance a step.

The master says:
Formless, traceless, nameless too,
Upholding heaven and earth from ancient times to now.
Just as Qing’an overturned it all—
Ding’an says: The great thousand worlds all turn to gold.
Wu’an says: Vast and without trace, beyond all seeking.
Fu’an says: Know that the point of entry is found in stillness.
Hei’an says: Transformed, the great earth becomes gold.
Yue’an says: Shattered into nothingness, without a trace.

The master says: Except for Wu’an, all have passed in one stroke.

The master says:
The tripod of heaven and golden furnace refine sun and moon,
The handle of the Big Dipper turns the celestial sphere.
Splitting open chaos, the golden elixir is complete—
Ding’an says: Only then does the true man attain his will.
Wu’an says: The Dao is fundamentally non-action, yet likened to action.
Hei’an says: This is the time before heaven and earth.
Ji’an says: Precisely the moment of transcending the ordinary and entering sagehood.

The master says: Ding’an’s line is supreme.

The master says:
Step forward and overturn the formless,
Lift your head and topple the Great Brahma Heaven.
If someone asks where I dwell—
Ding’an says: Breaking through the golden barrier, unbounded and free.
Wu’an says: A single speck contains the great thousand worlds.
Fu’an says: Hidden in the primordial chaos before the separation of foam.
Heiku says: Neither diminished nor increased, fundamentally natural.
Yue’an says: Only in the space between your brows and lashes.

The master says: Ding’an is first, Fu’an second.

The master says:
Through kalpas, it was ever a single pearl,
Hard as raw iron, soft as butter.
The great thousand worlds have no place to rest—
Ding’an says: Encompassing heaven and earth, the pattern of creation.
Wu’an says: Beyond the Dao, emptiness is inexhaustible.
Fu’an says: Illuminating the void, there is nothing at all.
Pu’an says: Seeing it clearly, there is nothing to seek afterward.
Hei’an says: Filling the void entirely, it is all this.
Aishan says: Boundless pure light illumines the great emptiness.

The master says: None have fully captured it, yet among them, Ding’an and Hei’an come closest.

The master says:
Clinging to non-being or being is not the work,
Abandoning both still falls into emptiness.
Only when neither is relied upon is there unity—
Ding’an says: True being arises from non-being, then subtly flows.
Hei’an says: Neither being nor non-being, only then is there perfect penetration.
Wu’an says: Neither being nor non-being reveals spiritual power.
Fu’an says: Only when the great void is one with the body is the Dao penetrated.

The master says: All come close.

I say: It would be better to silently abide within.

The master says:
Round and complete, a single circle,
Existing before the primordial chaos was divided.
Without stem or root, nothing to grasp—
Ding’an says: Only now is the true trap revealed.
Hei’an says: Present and fully functional in every application.
Wu’an says: Know that when the moon sets, it does not leave the sky.
Fu’an says: Still and unmoving, awakening to the true meaning.

The master says: Hei’an’s line is acceptable.

The master says:
Above, it props up heaven; below, it props up earth,
Yet in the center, a single aperture does not circulate *qi*.
Invisible to the eye, inaudible to the ear—
Ding’an says: Eating and dressing, ever unobscured.
Hei’an says: In every application, never apart.
Wu’an says: Filling the void, even spirits and ghosts fear it.
Sun’an says: How is it different from the void?

The master says: Ding’an’s line is acceptable.

The master further says:
Erect the tripod and dry up the four great seas,
Set the furnace and refine the five Mount Sumerus to dust.
The golden elixir takes form, encompassing the three realms—
Ding’an says: Only then does the true man attain his will.
Wu’an says: The Dao is fundamentally non-action, yet likened to action.
Hei’an says: This is the time before heaven and before earth.
Ji’an says: Precisely the moment of transcending the ordinary and entering sagehood.

The master says: Ding’an’s line is peerless.

The master was at Zhaoyang’s Four Sages Daoist Abbey, refining aspirations with his Dharma kin. These are appended here.

The master says:
Dip the brush-tip and the rivers and lakes run dry,
Grind the ink-stick and the great earth is pierced.
Sealing the void with a single stroke—
Hei’an says: From ancient times to now, misty as clouds and smoke.
Xi’an says: From the tip of the brush, the original heaven is revealed.
Tui’an says: Painting opens the time before parents were born.
Jing’an says: Beyond this mystery, there is no further mystery.

The master says: Jing’an and Tui’an come closest.
Tui’an’s line, if changed to "before the separation of chaos," would be even finer.

The master says:
Little brother An, little toad Chan,
Hidden away, not permitted for outsiders to see.
Last night, opening its mouth to swallow the sky—
Hei’an says: A belly full of cinnabar, the fire blazing.
Jing’an says: Chew it and know the bitter and the sweet.
Tui’an says: The great earth and mountains and rivers lie hidden beneath the tongue.
Yi’an says: A taste of supreme ghee, uniquely sweet.

The master says: All come close.

I say: Swallowing heaven and earth is still not enough.

chunks.original_text: 师曰：贫者今年成煞贫，庵中无地可容针。 贫来贫去贫无极，嘿庵曰：惟有金丹亘古今。 济庵曰：彻骨全无一点尘。 隐庵曰：赤条条地本来心。 虚庵曰：脱却皮肤见本心。 息庵曰：炼得乾坤总是金。 惟庵曰：唯有通身是紫金。 丁宰曰：独有神丹一粒金。 师曰：都未是。 答曰：家破人亡死却心。 师曰：黄婆昨夜养婴儿，才出胞胎体太微。 混沌之中藏不得，嘿庵曰：还他无极以前时。 息庵曰：却来黍米识玄机。 师曰：都是未着。 答曰：太虚之外斡璇玑。 师曰：闻经闻法事难全，离法求玄又不然。 不离不闻都是错，嘿庵曰：一切掀倒始功圆。 息庵曰：饥来吃饭困来眠。 师曰：皆未尽善。 答曰：执中不易是真诠。 师曰：竿头立底功难就，进步如何动脚跟。 不动脚跟争得到，嘿庵曰：上头一着妙难论。 师曰：揭开脑盖去朝元。 师又曰：坐中开眼道难成，闭眼元来又属阴。 不闭不开真瞎汉，嘿庵曰：通身是眼我知音。 济庵曰：放开一眼观教亲。 师曰：顶门具眼见天心。 师曰：若行陆地涉途程，水路来时堕堑坑。 不涉两途争得道，嘿庵曰：拦腮一掌太无情。 息庵曰：元来中道坦然平。 师曰：息庵较些子。 予则曰：乘风归去谒三清。 师曰：无门关锁不难参，说着无门便没关。 既是无关开个甚，嘿庵曰：知他窠臼有何难。 息庵曰：一拳打破透疑团。 虚庵曰：不移一步到长安。 师曰：虚庵可取。 师曰：坐中皆浊总为阴，及至惺惺又属情。 不散不昏都是垢，嘿庵曰：鼓琴招凤自然清。 一庵曰：万缘俱泯大丹成。 东庵曰：虚无空寂本乎诚。 静安曰：全身放下自通灵。 师曰：都欠些子。 答曰：放教自在便光明。 师曰：工夫做到杳冥中，守着些儿费了功。 不守又还成茫荡，嘿庵曰：此身全与太虚同。 息庵曰：息中自有大神通。 东庵曰：全身隐在太虚中。 一庵曰：寂然不动感而通。 师曰：拈来物外逞神通。 师又曰：昨夜三更日正午，大虫吞却南山虎。 清庵定裹逞神通，嘿庵曰：狮子吼时谁敢侮。 颐庵曰：撼动乾坤谁敢侮。 师曰：你两个都不识这个。 答曰：说得骊龙起来舞。 师曰：水中捞月从来妄，火裹栽莲是脱空。 獗地寻天多费力，嘿庵曰：不离当处阐神通。 息庵曰：无修无证始成功。 师曰：争如一定守其中。 又曰：天作庵儿地作基，四维八极作藩篱。 中间有个痴呆汉，嘿庵曰：独玩天心月上时。 师曰：索性掀翻不住持。 又曰：乾坤未判从无极，无极之前本太初。 未有太初前底事，嘿庵曰：渠今非我我非渠。 息庵曰：古今惟我独如如。 师曰：只今见在体元虚。 师曰：昨宵日午与无寥，直上中天旋斗杓。 运转法输天地震，嘿庵曰：泰珠宫裹正逍遥。 又曰：森罗万象悉来朝。 师曰：莫执无心与有心，两心到底不通真。 有心毕竟心为累，嘿庵曰：会取中间真有因。 师曰：无有双忘证法身。 又曰：我把杀人手段，拈出活人刀子。 试问杀活如何？ 嘿庵曰：活却从前死底。 息庵曰：斩断一切生死。 师曰：你两个刀子无刃。 答曰：法王法令在此。 师曰：烁烁团团一宝珠，外无边际裹头虚。 轻轻拈出无安处，嘿庵曰：独露单提得自如。 虚庵曰：遍周沙界现真如。 息庵曰：放去收来总在渠。 一庵曰：元始於中独自居。 师曰：你每安得不着下着。
chunks.translated_text:
The master says:
This year, the poor grow poorer still,
Not even room for a needle in the hut.
Poverty comes and goes, endless poverty—
Hei’an says: Only the golden elixir endures through ancient and modern times.
Ji’an says: Through the bones, not a speck of dust remains.
Yin’an says: Stripped bare, the original heart.
Xu’an says: Shedding the skin to see the true heart.
Xi’an says: Refining heaven and earth, all becomes gold.
Wei’an says: Only the whole body is purple gold.
Ding Zai says: Only the divine elixir, a single grain of gold.
The master says: None of these are it.
I answer: The household broken, the people gone, the heart dead.
The master says: Last night, the Yellow Dame gave birth to the infant,
Just emerged from the womb, its form too subtle.
It cannot hide within chaos—
Hei’an says: Return it to the time before the boundless.
Xi’an says: Then, in a grain of millet, recognize the mystery.
The master says: All still miss the mark.
I answer: Beyond the great void, the turning of the celestial pivot.
The master says:
Hearing scriptures and teachings, the task is never complete,
Seeking the mystery apart from the Dharma is also wrong.
Neither departing nor hearing—both are errors—
Hei’an says: Overturn everything, and the work is perfected.
Xi’an says: When hungry, eat; when tired, sleep.
The master says: None have fully grasped it.
I answer: Holding to the center without deviation is the true teaching.
The master says:
Standing at the tip of the pole, the work is hard to complete,
How to take a step forward without moving the feet?
If the feet do not move, how can one reach it?
Hei’an says: The supreme move above is wondrous beyond discussion.
The master says: Lift the skull’s lid and go to court the origin.
The master further says:
Sitting with eyes open, the Dao is hard to achieve,
Closing the eyes, it belongs to yin.
Neither closing nor opening—truly blind fools—
Hei’an says: The whole body is eyes, I know my kin.
Ji’an says: Open one eye to observe the teachings and kin.
The master says: The eye atop the head sees the heart of heaven.
The master says:
If walking on land, one traverses the path,
When the water route comes, one falls into the pit.
Not traversing both paths, how can one attain the Dao?
Hei’an says: A slap across the face—too merciless.
Xi’an says: Originally, the middle way is level and smooth.
The master says: Xi’an comes closest.
I say: Riding the wind back to pay homage to the Three Pure Ones.
The master says:
The gateless barrier is not hard to fathom,
Yet speaking of no gate, there is no barrier.
If there is no barrier, what is there to open?
Hei’an says: Knowing the nest’s pattern, what difficulty is there?
Xi’an says: A single fist shatters the web of doubt.
Xu’an says: Without moving a step, one arrives at Chang’an.
The master says: Xu’an is acceptable.
The master says:
Sitting amidst turbidity, all is yin,
When one awakens, it belongs to emotion.
Neither scattered nor dull—all is defilement—
Hei’an says: Playing the zither to summon the phoenix, naturally clear.
Yi’an says: All conditions extinguished, the great elixir is complete.
Dong’an says: Emptiness and quiescence are rooted in sincerity.
Jing’an says: Releasing the whole body, one naturally attains spirit.
The master says: All fall short.
I answer: Let it be free and at ease, then there is radiance.
The master says:
When the work is done in the depths of darkness,
Guarding even a little wastes the effort.
Not guarding, it becomes vast and boundless—
Hei’an says: This body is wholly one with the great void.
Xi’an says: Within stillness, there is great spiritual power.
Dong’an says: The whole body hides within the great void.
Yi’an says: Silent and unmoving, yet responsive and connected.
The master says: Bring it forth beyond things to display spiritual power.
The master further says:
Last night at midnight, the sun was at noon,
The great beast swallowed the tiger of South Mountain.
Within the clarity of concentration, spiritual power is displayed—
Hei’an says: When the lion roars, who dares insult?
Yi’an says: Shaking heaven and earth, who dares insult?
The master says: Neither of you recognizes this.
I answer: The words make the dragon of the deep rise and dance.
The master says:
Fishing for the moon in water has always been delusion,
Planting lotuses in fire is empty deception.
Rashly seeking heaven expends much effort—
Hei’an says: Not departing from the present, the spiritual power unfolds.
Xi’an says: Without cultivation or verification, the work is complete.
The master says: How does it compare to simply abiding within?
Again he says:
Heaven as the hut, earth as the foundation,
The four directions and eight extremes as the fence.
Within, there is a dull-witted man—
Hei’an says: Alone, he plays with the heart of heaven beneath the moon.
The master says: Better to overturn it all and not dwell.
Again he says:
Before heaven and earth divided, there was the boundless,
Before the boundless, there was the great beginning.
What was the matter before the great beginning?
Hei’an says: Now it is not me, and I am not it.
Xi’an says: Through ancient and modern, only I alone am thus.
The master says: Now, the original body is seen as empty.
The master says:
Last night at midnight, the sun was at noon,
Straight up to the center of heaven, turning the Dipper’s handle.
The turning of the Dharma wheel shakes heaven and earth—
Hei’an says: In the Palace of Great Jewels, truly at ease.
Again he says: The myriad phenomena all come to pay homage.
The master says:
Do not cling to mind or no-mind,
Both minds ultimately do not reach the truth.
Having mind is ultimately a burden—
Hei’an says: Grasping the center, there is truly a cause.
The master says: Forgetting both, one verifies the Dharma-body.
Again he says:
I wield the hand of a killer,
Brandishing the blade that gives life.
I ask you, how to kill and give life?
Hei’an says: Giving life to what was previously dead.
Xi’an says: Severing all birth and death.
The master says: Neither of your blades has an edge.
I answer: The Dharma-king’s decree is here.
The master says:
A radiant, round pearl,
Without boundary outside, empty within.
Gently lifting it, there is no place to set it—
Hei’an says: Alone, it reveals itself, naturally at ease.
Xu’an says: Pervading the sand-realm, the true thusness appears.
Xi’an says: Whether releasing or gathering, all is within it.
Yi’an says: The origin dwells alone within.
The master says: How could you all not be attached?

chunks.original_text: 咦，引我蟾蝫裹面居。 又曰：炼就通红热铁丸，红如杲日大如天。 钳来送入诸人口，嘿庵曰：嚼出清凉一味禅。 息庵曰：嚼碎方知滋味全。 师曰：烂尽肝肠性始坚。 师曰：予与诸法眷续诗游戏，予之本意不在诗而在道，苟有以诗会道者，无上至正之妙得矣。 今以挽邪归正为题，押爷遮韵，作一绝句，证不许犯题。 嘿庵曰：堪笑迷徒不认家，唤他假老作亲爷。 嘿庵伸出无为手，直指长安无障遮。 实庵曰：曲径傍蹊数百家，人人错认贼为爷。 我今唤得回头了，方信蓬莱路不遮。 甲庵曰：三千小法眼前花，切莫迷漫唤作爷。 蓦鼻拖回归大道，满天明月没云遮。 师曰：抱贼叫屈实堪嗟，两眼明明不识爷。 莫怪清庵施毒手，打开心孔要无遮。 清庵茔蟾子语录卷之四竟 清庵莹蟾子语录卷之五 门弟子蒙庵张应坦编 杂述
chunks.translated_text:
Ah! Drawing me to dwell within the toad’s moon.
Again he says:
Forged into a searing red iron pellet,
Crimson as the blazing sun, vast as the heavens.
Clamped and fed into every mouth—
Hei’an says: Chewing, one tastes the cool, singular Chan.
Xi’an says: Only when crushed is the full flavor known.
The master says: When liver and bowels rot away, the nature first hardens.

The master says: I play with poetry among the assembly of Dharma kin, yet my true intent lies not in verse but in the Dao. Should one grasp the Dao through poetry, the supreme, perfectly upright wonder is attained.

Now, taking "Turning the Deviant Back to the Right" as the theme and rhyming with *ye zhe*, I compose a quatrain to prove that the theme must not be violated.
Hei’an says:
How laughable, the deluded disciples who fail to know their home—
They hail some false elder as their own father.
Hei’an extends the hand of non-action,
Pointing straight to Chang’an without hindrance.

Shi’an says:
A winding path beside the byway, hundreds of households—
Each mistakes a thief for father.
Now that I’ve called them to turn their heads,
They trust at last the road to Penglai is unobstructed.

Jia’an says:
Three thousand lesser dharmas bloom before the eye—
Take care not to be misled, calling them father.
Seizing by the nose, I drag them back to the great Dao,
Where the bright moon fills the sky, unclouded.

The master says:
To clasp a thief and cry injustice—how lamentable!
With eyes wide open, they still fail to recognize their father.
No wonder Qing’an wields a ruthless hand—
Shattering the heart’s aperture to demand boundlessness.

*Record of Master Qing’an Yingchan, Scroll Four (concluded)*
*Record of Master Qing’an Yingchan, Scroll Five*
Compiled by disciple Meng’an Zhang Yingtan
*Miscellaneous Accounts*

chunks.original_text: 诗赠东溪 丹道立基处，休教外境侵。 一心才静定，二物互相任。 离火烧铅汞，雷车运水金。 调和藉坤土，灌溉必天壬。 白雪凝金鼎，黄芽长玉簪。 这些真种子，本不是玄参。 又 会得潜心妙，从他上鼠侵。 有人信得及，无个力难任。 慈誓弘如海，机锋利似金。 穷通内子午，掀倒外丁壬。 善闭无关键，勿疑朋盍簪。 玄之又玄处，一唯契曾参。 韩宰求赞吕祖师 这个吕老，面善心黑。 兀兀腾腾，飘飘逸逸。 剑佩青蛇，丹传紫极。 校勘将来，分明奇特。 奇特一句，又作么生。 咄，袖中神剑，不露锋铓，宇宙纵横，了无人识。 王居士求赞宝公顶相 这个和尚，拗服背棒。 三十六场，做尽模样。 咦，直待擘破面皮，露出裹头端相。 张居士求赞布袋和尚 这个胖汉，惯会做贼。 布袋中藏，了无人识。 咦，自是贼人心下虚，笑中露出真消息。 李居士求赞吕公 个样胡汉，是何像态。 兀兀腾腾，捏捏怪怪。 寄迹红尘，遨游物外。 既到这裹，私脏尽败。 且道贼在甚处？ 咄，袖内隐青蛇，粟中藏世界。 善友求赞王祖师 这个老叟，形容大丑。 发少如须，眼大似口。 自称是五祖儿孙，人唤作七真师友。 且道如何，即是看口。 更问如何，劈脊便搂。 赵居士求赞三仙图 祖师清庵，黄胖黄胖，全不似像。 百无一能，受人供养。 还识真底么？
chunks.translated_text:
**Poem Presented to Dongxi**

Where the elixir-path takes root,
Let no external realm intrude.
Once the heart settles into stillness,
Dual forces yield to one another.

Fire of departure refines lead and mercury,
Thunder’s chariot conveys water and metal.
Harmony relies on earth’s receptive power—
Irrigation must draw from heaven’s *ren*.

White snow congeals in the golden crucible,
Yellow sprouts grow like jade hairpins.
These are the true seeds—
Not *xuanshen* in disguise.

**Another Poem**

Grasp the subtlety of hidden mind,
And let thieving rats invade at will.
If one truly believes,
No force is too great to bear.

Vows of compassion vast as the sea,
Skillful means sharp as tempered steel.
Within, the *zi-wu* axis turns;
Without, *ding-ren* is overturned.

Sealed with no lock or key,
Doubt not the gathering of friends.
In the mystery upon mystery,
Only one accords with Zeng Can.

---

**Eulogy for Magistrate Han’s Request to Praise Patriarch Lü**

This old Lü—
A kind face, a dark heart.
Drifting, soaring,
Unfettered, free.

A sword girded with a green serpent,
The elixir transmitted to the Purple Pole.
Examined closely,
His distinction is clear.

Yet what is this distinction?
Hark!
A divine blade hidden in his sleeve,
Its edge unseen—
Roaming the cosmos,
Known by none.

---

**Eulogy for Layman Wang’s Request to Praise Master Bao’s Portrait**

This monk—
Stubborn, his back to the staff.
Thirty-six performances,
Each a different guise.

Hmph!
Wait until his face is torn open,
Revealing the true visage beneath.

---

**Eulogy for Layman Zhang’s Request to Praise Hotei, the Cloth-Bag Monk**

This portly fellow—
A thief by trade.
What’s hidden in his cloth bag?
None can tell.

Hmph!
The thief’s heart is ever uneasy—
A smile betrays the truth.

---

**Eulogy for Layman Li’s Request to Praise Patriarch Lü**

What manner of foreigner is this?
Such a strange bearing—
Drifting, soaring,
Twisted, bizarre.

Dwelling in the red dust,
Yet roaming beyond the world.
Once here,
His stolen goods are all exposed.

Where, then, does the thief hide?
Hark!
A green serpent concealed in his sleeve,
A world hidden in a grain of millet.

---

**Eulogy for Shan You’s Request to Praise Patriarch Wang**

This old codger—
A face most unsightly.
Hair sparse as whiskers,
Eyes wide as his mouth.

He claims descent from the Fifth Patriarch,
Yet men call him friend to the Seven Perfected.
How so?
Just look at his mouth.
And if you ask further—
A strike to the back, and he’s upon you.

---

**Eulogy for Layman Zhao’s Request to Praise the Three Immortals**

Master Qing’an—
Yellow and plump, yellow and plump,
Not at all as he seems.
Skilled in nothing,
Yet sustained by others’ offerings.

Do you recognize the truth beneath?

For him, you split open your face,
Yet it becomes no different from empty space.

Jie’an, the pedant, points with his thumb—
A thousand oddities, a hundred grotesqueries.
Having read the books of five carts,
Not a single word does he comprehend.
And why does he not comprehend?
Hark!
Shed the motley of the old comic actor,
To win the indestructible vajra-body.

**Eulogies for the Dharma Assembly**

**Li Chan’s Eulogy:**
The moon of the heart, round and bright,
The sky of nature, radiant and clear.
Forth leaps the toad,
Illumining heaven and earth.

**Mo’an’s Eulogy:**
Mo’an’s realm—
No within, no without.
Vast in embrace, all-containing,
Magnanimous and resplendent.

**Dan Chan’s Eulogy:**
Cinnabar serves the toad’s use,
The toad embodies cinnabar’s essence.
When cinnabar is perfected, the toad sloughs off,
Its merit equal to the Primordial Beginning.

**Yi Chan’s Eulogy:**
The zenith of meditation, lustrous and still,
The sea of wisdom, limpid and clear.
One toad bursts forth,
Shining universally upon the insentient.

Hark! Heaven and earth shatter under a hundred pressures,
Revealing alone the great radiance.

**Yi’an’s Eulogy:**
Yi’an’s realm—
No entanglements, no obstructions.
When the ninefold transmutation is complete,
The numinous embryo sheds its husk.
Ah!
From the crown emits a great radiance,
Pervading the three-thousandfold world.

**Eulogy for Li Daishao**
With keen discernment, he corrects his bearing,
Parting the clouds to cultivate the moon.

chunks.original_text: 向上工夫，一切漏泄。 咦，至士面前呈手段，到头万法一齐通。 赞钱待韶 玉掠拨开云，金刀修出月。 上头些子机，一切都通彻。 咦，面前消息子，不闻中露泄。 杂颂 题三境图 看这一个拙汉，全无些子果断。 分明半死半活，犹自厮缠斯绊。 咦，连忙急走回来，也只救得一半。 题打坐猿 这个畜生，颠劣忒煞。 突出眼睛，野性犹在。 咄，直须烂了皮毛，物外纵横无碍。 题闭目猿 咄这毛团，是何相态。 一味颠狂，千般捏怪。 既到这裹，和脏捉败。 且道脏在甚处。 咦，瞑心瞑目坐山巅，全炁全神游物外。 赞黑杀符 虚空为纸，须弥作笔。 尽就灵符，神出鬼没，试问煞活如何堑。 赞剑 杀人刀子，横拈倒举。 逢佛杀佛，逢鬼杀鬼。 赞烧饼 水面和成一块，做出圆陀陀地。 不因火候工夫，争得个般真味。 咄，信手拈出向君，不用牙关嚼碎。 赞饧糖 绞出黄芽汁，煎熬凭火力。 黏如鸾凤胶，甜似彼罗蜜。 懵懂拙汉，黏却牙关。 大力量人，开口不得。 赞瓢 禀赋先天一炁，成就个般道器。 拈来信手劈开，浑沦圆陀陀地。 咦，举起分明，切忌错会。 又云：只－这一个把柄，妙用神功莫测？ 举起盖日遮天，放下风恬浪息。 赞宗髼头 髼头髼头，有甚风流。 横拖拄杖，倒骑铁牛。 自赞真相 这个面觜，不傍道理。 那个尚非，何尝有你。

**On Superior Work:**
All leaks and seepages—
Ah!
Before the perfected one, display your skill,
And in the end, the myriad dharmas all become thoroughly clear.

**Eulogy for Qian Daishao**
Jade comb parts the clouds,
Golden blade carves out the moon.
At the summit, that subtle mechanism—
All is penetrated and made clear.
Ah!
The message before your face,
Unheard, yet revealed within.

**Miscellaneous Eulogies**

**Inscription on the Three Realms Diagram**
Behold this clumsy fellow,
Utterly devoid of resolve.
Half-dead, half-alive,
Still entangled and ensnared.
Ah!
Hurry back in haste—
Yet only half may be saved.

**Inscription on the Meditating Ape**
This brute,
Wild and unruly to the extreme.
Eyes bulging,
Savage nature still intact.
Hark!
Only when its hide is flayed,
Will it roam freely beyond all things, unobstructed.

**Inscription on the Eyes-Closed Ape**
Hark! This furred lump—
What manner of form is this?
Ever raving, ever mad,
A thousand grotesqueries contrived.
Having come to this,
It is caught red-handed in its filth.
Now, where lies the filth?
Ah!
With heart and eyes closed, seated atop the mountain,
Whole in qi, whole in spirit, it wanders beyond the world of things.

**Eulogy for the Black Killing Talisman**
Void as paper,
Mount Sumeru as brush.
Inscribed upon the numinous talisman,
Spirits appear and vanish—
Try asking: how is the killing made alive?

**Eulogy for the Sword**
A blade that slays men,
Brandished horizontally, inverted, raised.
Encounter a buddha, slay the buddha;
Encounter a ghost, slay the ghost.

**Eulogy for the Sesame Cake**
Kneaded into a single mass upon the water,
Shaped into perfect roundness.
Without the skill of fire’s refinement,
How could such true flavor be attained?
Hark!
Plucked forth and offered to you—
No need to grind it between your teeth.

**Eulogy for Malt Sugar**
The juice of yellow sprouts is pressed,
Simmered and tempered by fire’s power.
Sticky as phoenix glue,
Sweet as that heavenly honey.
The dull and clumsy—
Their jaws are sealed shut.
The mighty—
Cannot open their mouths.

**Eulogy for the Gourd**
Endowed with the primordial qi,
Fashioned into such a vessel of the Dao.
Lifted and split with ease,
Whole and perfectly round.
Ah!
Hold it aloft—clearly now,
Beware of misconstruing.
It is said:
This single handle—
Its wondrous function and divine workings unfathomable?
Raised, it veils the sun and covers the sky;
Lowered, the wind stills and the waves subside.

**Eulogy for the Unkempt Sage**
Unkempt head, unkempt head—
What charm does it possess?
A staff dragged aslant,
An iron ox ridden backward.

**Self-Eulogy of True Form**
This face and mouth,
Adheres to no principle.
That which is not yet—
How could it ever have been yours?

chunks.original_text: 咦，唤作李清庵，便是眼见鬼。 赞扇 圆陀陀地一片，直下森罗影现。 举起明月当天，摇动清风拂面。 且道见也不见。 咦，休问见也不见，为伊略通一线，搧一扇。 赞丹 亘古此物，无形无质。 无欠无余，无休无息。 其利断金，其圆胜日。 释曰玄珠，儒曰太极。 道曰金丹，名三体一。 只在目前，时人不识。 ○只这便是，休更疑惑。 示众二图 颂　头　藏　字　迭 脱蜕　元形　保精 成丹　神炼　气御 久视　　　　存神 生长　　　　定性 形固　气灵　心明 凝精　住神　本悟 释颂 元神炼形，炼形保精。 保精御气，御气神存。 神存定性，定性明心。 明心悟本，悟本神灵。 神灵气住，气住精凝。 精凝形固，形固长生。 长生久视，久视丹成。 丹成脱蜕，脱蜕元神。 右此颂乃炼神之要也。 欲炼其神，先炼其精。 欲炼其精，先御其炁。 欲御其炁，必先存守。 存守得定，则心所以明，神所以灵，炁所以住也。 炁住而后精凝，精凝而后形固，形固而阳神脱蜕，长生久视之道尽矣。 丹书所谓金液炼形，金液还丹，并不外乎此。 还　丹　之　图 释图律诗 八金釜内炼丹时， 八者，木之成数也。 木，性也。 金，情也。 以性摄情，入于中宫，喻曰土釜。 然后加火炼之，愈炼愈坚固，愈炼愈圆明，故喻之曰金丹也。 户火炉中要谨持。 火者，神也。 户者，室也。 元神入室，如药在炉，切宜谨谨固济，勿令差失。 铅汞二物，惟好飞走，可不谨乎。 毫发差殊，不作丹者是也。 欠土坎宫壬癸走， 土者，坤也。 坤属身，身不动则虎啸，身动则虎走。 虎啸则精凝，虎走则精泄。 欠土者，身不定也。 壬癸走者，精泄也。 学者不可不谨。 心生性地丙丁飞。 丙丁，火也，属心。 心定则龙吟，心不定则龙奔。 龙吟则炁固，龙奔则炁散。 心生者，火炎也。 丙丁飞者，气散也。 此二句喻铅飞汞走之意也。 主人住处阴魔伏， 主人者，本来真如之性也。 历劫不坏，元神也。 住者，元神入室也。 阴魔伏者，情欲绝也。 学道底人，身心既不动，则神凝气固矣。 日月明时至宝辉。 日月，喻身之精华也。 明者，精华凝结也。 功深力到，炼成一块至宝，放光辉照天烁地也。 一二三元成混合 天一生水，精也。 地二生火，气也。 天三生木，神也。 精气神炼成一块，三五合一，返本还元。 金公铋死抱婴儿。 金边着个公字，铅也。 铅死者，欲海竭也，情念绝也，圣胎成也，婴兄显象也。 一铋二汞会三宫， 一者，水之生数，喻精也，强名曰铅。 二者，火之生数，喻气也，强名曰砂。 三者，木之生数，喻神也，强名曰汞。 三宫者，三元所居之宫也。 东海金公百炼工 东海，喻性也。 金公，喻情也。 即是铅汞之异名，情来归性以火炼。 百炼工夫方为至宝。 身内本元为体用， 自家身内有天然种子，向外求之者谬矣。 身内元精，金丹之用也。 心中元气，金丹之体也。 艮宫木液是根宗。 艮宫即土也，木液即汞也，总名曰砂中汞，金丹之母也。 恐学者无以取则，故强名云。 日居月窟真明了， 日居月窟者，阳来阴舍也，取坎填离也，抽铅添汞也，婴儿交姹女也，金木并也，水火交也。 心死神生慧性通。 心死则神生，神生则慧通，故学道之人，身如朽木，心若死灰，寂然不动。 工夫纯熟，慧性圆明。

Ah!
Call it Li Qing’an,
And you’ve already seen a ghost.

**Eulogy for the Fan**
Perfectly round, a single slice—
Beneath it, the shadows of the ten thousand things appear.
Raised, the bright moon fills the sky;
Waved, a pure breeze brushes the face.
Now tell me—do you see it or not?
Ah!
Ask not whether you see it or not.
For it grants but a single thread of passage—
Flick it once.

**Eulogy for the Elixir**
This thing since time immemorial,
Formless, without substance.
No lack, no excess,
No end, no pause.
Its edge cuts through metal,
Its roundness surpasses the sun.
The Buddhists call it the *Dark Pearl*,
The Confucians call it the *Great Ultimate*.
The Daoists call it the *Golden Elixir*—
Three names, one body.
It lies right before your eyes,
Yet people fail to recognize it.
○ This is it—
No more doubt.

**Two Diagrams for Instruction**

**Eulogy for the Character "藏" (Store)**
Shedding the husk—preserve the primordial form.
Guard the essence—refine into elixir.
Refine the spirit—master the qi.
Prolong vision—abide in spirit.
Nurture growth—stabilize nature.
Form solid—qi numinous—heart luminous.
Essence congealed—spirit settled—root awakened.

**Explanatory Eulogy**
Refine the spirit to temper the form,
Temper the form to guard the essence.
Guard the essence to master the qi,
Master the qi to abide in spirit.
Abide in spirit to stabilize nature,
Stabilize nature to illuminate the heart.
Illuminate the heart to awaken the root,
Awaken the root to make the spirit numinous.
Numinous spirit—qi settled,
Qi settled—essence congealed.
Essence congealed—form solid,
Form solid—longevity attained.
Longevity—vision prolonged,
Vision prolonged—elixir perfected.
Elixir perfected—husk shed,
Husk shed—primordial spirit.
To the right, this eulogy encapsulates the essence of spirit refinement.
To refine the spirit, first refine the essence.
To refine the essence, first master the qi.
To master the qi, first abide in stillness.
Abiding in stillness brings clarity to the heart,
Numinosity to the spirit,
And stability to the qi.
Qi stabilized, essence congeals;
Essence congealed, form solidifies.
Form solidified, the yang spirit sheds its husk—
The Way of longevity and prolonged vision is complete.
The alchemical texts speak of *golden liquid refining the form*,
*Golden liquid returning as elixir*—
None stray from this path.

**Diagram of the Returning Elixir**

**Explanatory Verse for the Diagram**
Within the eightfold golden crucible, the elixir is refined.
Eight is the completion number of wood—
Wood is nature, gold is emotion.
Subduing emotion with nature,
Entering the central palace—
Metaphorically called the *earthen crucible*.
Then, with fire, refine it:
The more it is refined, the more steadfast it becomes,
The more it is refined, the more round and luminous—
Hence the metaphor of the *Golden Elixir*.
Guard it closely within the chambered furnace.
Fire is spirit,
The chamber is the crucible.
The primordial spirit enters the chamber,
Like medicine in the furnace—
Tend it with utmost care,
Lest the slightest error be made.
Lead and mercury, ever prone to flee—
How could one not be vigilant?
A hair’s breadth of deviation,
And no elixir is formed.

Lacking earth, in the Kan palace, Ren and Gui escape.
Earth is Kun—
Kun governs the body.
When the body is still, the tiger roars;
When the body moves, the tiger flees.
The tiger’s roar congeals the essence,
The tiger’s flight scatters it.
"Lacking earth" means the body is unsettled;
"Ren and Gui escape" means the essence is lost.
Scholars cannot afford to be careless.

When the heart stirs, in the nature’s domain, Bing and Ding take flight.
Bing and Ding are fire, belonging to the heart.
When the heart is settled, the dragon sings;
When the heart is restless, the dragon bolts.
The dragon’s song solidifies the qi,
The dragon’s flight scatters it.
"Heart stirs" means the fire blazes;
"Bing and Ding take flight" means the qi disperses.
These two lines illustrate the flight of lead and the escape of mercury.

Where the master abides, yin demons are subdued.
The master is the original true nature,
The indestructible primordial spirit.
"Abides" means the primordial spirit enters the chamber.
"Yin demons subdued" means desires are extinguished.
For those who cultivate the Dao:
When body and heart are still,
Spirit congeals and qi solidifies.

The bright moon and sun—timely treasures radiant.
The sun and moon symbolize the essence of the body.
"Bright" means the essence has congealed.
With deep practice and effort,
Refining it into a single precious treasure,
Its radiance shines through heaven and earth.

The one, two, three—primordial elements merge as one.
Heaven-one generates water—essence.
Earth-two generates fire—qi.
Heaven-three generates wood—spirit.
Essence, qi, and spirit refined into one,
The three and five unite—returning to the root.

Old Man Gold lies dead, embracing the infant.
The character *gold* with *public* beside it is lead.
"Lead dies" means the sea of desire is exhausted,
Passions extinguished,
The sacred embryo formed,
The infant revealed.

One lead, two mercury meet in the three palaces.
One is the generative number of water—essence,
Metaphorically called lead.
Two is the generative number of fire—qi,
Metaphorically called cinnabar.
Three is the generative number of wood—spirit,
Metaphorically called mercury.
The three palaces are where the three primordials reside.

Eastern Sea’s Old Man Gold—refined a hundredfold.
The Eastern Sea symbolizes nature,
Old Man Gold symbolizes emotion—
Another name for lead and mercury.
Emotion returns to nature, refined by fire.
Only through a hundredfold refinement does it become the supreme treasure.

Within the body, the primordial serves as substance and function.
Within one’s own body lies the natural seed—
To seek it externally is folly.
The body’s primordial essence is the function of the Golden Elixir,
The heart’s primordial qi is its substance.

The wood-fluid of the Gen palace is the root and origin.
The Gen palace is earth,
The wood-fluid is mercury—
Together called *mercury within cinnabar*,
The mother of the Golden Elixir.
Lest scholars lack a standard,
These names are provisionally given.

The sun dwells in the moon’s cavern—truly luminous.
"Sun dwells in the moon’s cavern" means yang enters the yin chamber,
Drawing from Kan to fill Li,
Extracting lead to replenish mercury,
The infant and the maiden unite,
Metal and wood merge,
Water and fire commingle.

When the heart dies, the spirit lives—wisdom’s nature flows.
When the heart dies, the spirit lives;
When the spirit lives, wisdom flows.
Thus, those who cultivate the Dao:
The body like withered wood,
The heart like dead ashes,
Utterly still.
With practice perfected,
Wisdom’s nature becomes round and luminous.

chunks.translated_text:
When the work is complete and the water dries, lead and mercury conjoin.
When the practice is fully perfected, the sea of desire naturally dries up.
When nature and emotion merge as one, mercury and lead intertwine.
When the fire-phase’s work is accomplished, form and spirit transcend.
Only then does the Golden Elixir take shape.

*A single grain of the Great Elixir shines through heaven’s red—*
The Great Elixir is the Great Ultimate’s perfection.
Not formed from external things, but refined from the original true suchness.
When a person ingests and returns to it, they fruitfully attain the Golden Immortal.

**In cultivating the Dao, first clarify the Three, Two, and One—**
The Three, Two, and One are essence, qi, and spirit.
Not the essence of intercourse, the qi of breath, or the spirit of thought,
But the original essence, original qi, and original spirit.
This must not remain unclear.

**In practicing the work, do not indulge the arising of the heart-mind.**
During the practice, do not let the heart-mind wander.
When the heart arises, fire flares upward; when the heart is settled, ignorance ceases.
Throughout the twelve hours, constantly examine and restrain.

**If people of this age would trust my words,**
Those who study the Dao cling to texts and fixate on images, never attaining clarity themselves.
Laozi said: *My words are very easy to know, very easy to practice,
Yet the world cannot know them, cannot practice them—such is the lack of trust.*

**Strike and unite heaven and earth to house the true master.**
Heaven and earth are body and heart.
Those who truly trust strike and unite body and heart to recognize their original face.
If you meet face-to-face, you will decisively realize no coming, no going.

**Kan-water’s waves surge due to lack of earth—**
Kan-water’s waves surge when essence does not abide.
"Lack of earth" means the body is unsettled.
As the *Elixir Scriptures* say: *True earth restrains true lead.* This is it.

**When the nature-heaven stirs thoughts, the arising heart is born—**
When the nature-heaven stirs thoughts, emotions move within.
"The arising heart" is distraction.
As the *Elixir Scriptures* say: *True lead restrains true mercury.* This is it.

**To establish the mercury furnace, first work with water—**
In setting up the furnace and establishing the tripod, first stabilize essence—hence "first work with water."
When essence is stabilized, qi congeals.
Lead and mercury naturally conjoin.
As the *Elixir Scriptures* say: *Lead and mercury return to the earthen cauldron.*

**Within the cauldron, harmonize and refine the Eight Metals—**
The Eight Metals are emotion and nature.
The cauldron is the Yellow Center.
When nature and emotion return to the center, body and heart become profoundly still.
As the *Elixir Scriptures* say: *Body and heart still and unmoving.* This is it.

**When eyes droop in sleep, work with water-mercury—**
During practice, the demon of sleep disrupts.
In sleep, draw fire from water to attack mercury.

**When the heart’s breath settles, refine the Eastern Metal—**
When body and heart are unmoving, metal and wood merge.
When breath settles, refine—
The one nature becomes round and luminous, all conditions cease.

**The cart moves because the axle turns—I awaken to the heart-mind—**
The cart moves because the axle turns; people move because the heart moves.
When the axle turns, awakening—
One who understands this principle attains perfection.

**The Three Palaces, Two, and One—sun and moon shine bright—**
The Three Origins unite as one; the two substances become round.
The Three Palaces shine—
Bright as the sun and moon, they illumine heaven and earth.

Meng’an said: *Master Qing’an composed these two nested-character and hidden-head poems not to indulge in cleverness,
But to elucidate the substance and function of the Golden Elixir, revealing the subtlest without gap.
The nested-character ode speaks of the Elixir’s substance; the hidden-head poem, of its function.
The hidden-head’s intent expresses the Elixir Dao’s subtlety,
While the self-explication of its details makes the Elixir’s principles manifest.
If one views the diagrams and grasps the meaning, the Golden Elixir’s work is complete.*
Thus, he appended them to the collection to share with fellow cultivators.

*Qing’an Yingchan’s Record, Volume Five concludes*
*Qing’an Yingchanzi’s Record, Volume Six*

chunks.original_text: 门弟子损庵蔡志头编 黄中解惑#1 师曰：前代祖师高真上圣，有无上正真之道，留传在世度人，公还知否？ 定庵曰：弟子初进玄门，至愚且蠢，蒙师收留，千载之幸也。 无上正真之道诚未知之，望师开发。 师曰：无上正真之道者，无上可上，玄之又玄，无象可象，自然而然，至极至妙之谓也。 圣人强名曰道。 自古上仙，皆由此处了达，未有不由是而修证者。 圣师口口，历代心心所传所授金丹之旨，乃无上正真之妙道也。 定庵曰：无上正真之妙，喻为金丹。 其理云何？ 师曰：一金者，坚也。 丹者，圆也。 释氏喻之为圆觉，儒家喻之为太极。 太极初非别物，只是本来一灵而已。 本来真性，永劫不壤，如金之坚，如丹之圆，愈炼愈明。 释氏曰：○此者，真如也。 儒家曰：○此者，太极也。 吾道曰：○此者，乃金丹也。 体同名异。 《易》曰：易有太极，是生两仪。 太极者，虚无自然之谓也。 两仪，一阴一阳也，天地也。 人生於天地之间，是谓江才之道，一身备矣。 太极者，元神也。 两仪者，身心也。 以丹道言之，太极者，丹之母也； 两仪者，真铅真汞也一所谓铅汞者，非水银、朱砂硫黄、黑锡、草木之类，亦非精津涕唾、心肾气血，乃身中元精，心中元神，身心不动，精炁凝结，喻之曰丹。 所谓丹者，丹身也。 ○此真性也。 丹中取出○者，谓之丹－成。 所谓丹者，非假外物而造作，由所生之本，而成正真也。 世鲜知之，今之修舟之士，多不得正传，皆是向外寻求，随邪背正，所以学者多而成者少。 或炼五金八石，或炼三避五假，或炼云霞外炁； 或炼日月精华，或采星曜之光，或想空中丸块而成丹者。 或想丹田有物而为丹，或肘后飞金精，或存想眉间，或还精补脑，或运炁归脐。 乃至服牍吞津，纳新吐故，八段锦，三字法，摇夹脊，绞辘轳，闭尾闾，守脐蒂，采天癸，煅秋石，曲伸导引，按摩消息，默朝上帝，舌柱上腭，三田返还，闭塞行炁，大火聚於膀胱，五行钻於苦海。 如斯小法，何啻千门。 纵有勤功采取，终不能成其大事。 经云：正法难遇多迷，真路多入邪宗，此之谓也。 夫至真之要，至简至易，难遇而易成。 若遇至人点化，无不成就。 定庵曰：弟子夙缘有幸，得遇老师，幸沾法乳，金丹之要，望赐点化。 师曰：汝今谛听，当为演说。 夫炼丹者，全在夺天地造化。 以乾坤为鼎器，以日月为水火，以阴阳为化机，以乌兔为药物，仗天罡之斡运，凭斗柄之推迁，采炁有时，运符有则，进火退符，和合四象，追二炁归黄道，会三性於元宫，返本还元，归根复命，功圆神备，凡脱为仙，谓之丹成也。 定庵曰：天地造化，诚恐难夺。 师曰：无出一身，奚难之有。 天地，形体也； 水火，精炁也； 阴阳，身心也； 乌兔，性情也。 所以形体为鼎炉，精炁为水火，情性为化机，身心为药材。 圣 人恐学者无以取则，遂以天地喻之。 人身与天地造化，无有不同处。 身心两个字，是药也，是火也。 所以天魂地魄，乾马坤牛，阳铅阴汞，坎男离女，日乌月兔，无出於身心二字。 天罡斡运者，天心也。 丹书云：人心若与天心合，颠倒阴阳止片时。 又云：以心观道，道即心也； 以道观心，心即道也。
chunks.translated_text:
The disciple Sun’an Cai Zhi recorded this:

**Yellow Center Resolves Doubts #1**

The Master said: *The ancestral masters, perfected beings, and highest sages of former ages possessed the Supreme Correct and True Dao, which they transmitted to the world to deliver people. Do you truly understand this?*

Ding’an replied: *This disciple has only just entered the Mystery Gate—utterly foolish and dull. Yet by your grace, Master, I have been accepted, a fortune of a thousand lifetimes. The Supreme Correct and True Dao I do not yet know; I humbly beseech your instruction.*

The Master said: *The Supreme Correct and True Dao is that which admits no higher, the most profound of the profound, beyond all form or image, spontaneously so—utterly perfect and wondrous. The sages were compelled to name it the Dao. Since ancient times, all transcendent immortals have attained realization through this, and none have achieved cultivation without it. The oral transmission of the sacred masters, the heart-to-heart transmission of successive generations—the essential teaching of the Golden Elixir—is precisely the wondrous Dao of the Supreme Correct and True.*

Ding’an said: *The Supreme Correct and True’s wondrousness is likened to the Golden Elixir. What is its principle?*

The Master said: *The character "gold" (金) signifies firmness; "elixir" (丹), roundness. The Buddhists compare it to Perfect Enlightenment; the Confucians, to the Supreme Ultimate. The Supreme Ultimate is no other thing—it is simply the original, singular numen. The original true nature is indestructible through endless kalpas, firm as gold, round as cinnabar, growing ever brighter with refinement. The Buddhists say: "○ This is True Suchness." The Confucians say: "○ This is the Supreme Ultimate." Our Dao says: "○ This is the Golden Elixir." The substance is the same; only the names differ.*

*The Book of Changes states: "In Change there is the Supreme Ultimate, which generates the Two Modes." The Supreme Ultimate is the designation for the spontaneous and formless. The Two Modes are the one yin and one yang—Heaven and Earth. Humanity is born between Heaven and Earth; this is called the Dao of Jiang Cai, and it is fully contained within the single body. The Supreme Ultimate is the primordial spirit; the Two Modes are body and mind. In terms of the Elixir Dao, the Supreme Ultimate is the mother of the Elixir; the Two Modes are true lead and true mercury.*

*What is called lead and mercury is not quicksilver, cinnabar, sulfur, black tin, or herbs and trees; nor is it the essences, fluids, snivel, spittle, heart-kidney qi, or blood. Rather, it is the primordial essence within the body and the primordial spirit within the heart. When body and mind are unmoving, essence and qi congeal and coalesce—this is likened to the Elixir. What is called the Elixir is the Elixir Body. ○ This is the true nature. Extracting ○ from the Elixir is called Elixir Accomplishment. The so-called Elixir is not fabricated from external things; it is the fulfillment of the original source, the attainment of the Correct and True.*

*Few in the world understand this. Today’s cultivators of the Dao mostly lack correct transmission; they all seek outwardly, following the deviant and turning from the correct. Thus, though many study, few succeed. Some refine the five metals and eight stones; some refine the three refuges and five counterfeits; some refine the qi beyond the clouds and mist; some refine the essence and brilliance of the sun and moon; some gather the light of the stars; some imagine pellets forming in empty space to become the Elixir. Some imagine objects in the cinnabar field to be the Elixir; some fly the golden essence from behind the elbow; some visualize between the brows; some return essence to replenish the brain; some circulate qi to return it to the navel. Then there are those who swallow saliva and ingest fluids, inhale the new and exhale the old, practice the Eight Brocades, the Three-Character Method, shake the spine, turn the windlass, close the Tail Gate, guard the navel’s stem, gather heavenly water, calcine autumn stone, bend and stretch in daoyin, massage and regulate, silently pay homage to the Supreme Emperor, press the tongue to the upper palate, return the three fields, close and conduct qi, amass great fire in the bladder, or drill the five phases into the bitter sea. Such minor methods number in the thousands. Even with diligent effort and gathering, they ultimately cannot accomplish the great work.*

*The scriptures say: "The correct Dharma is hard to encounter, and many go astray; the true path often leads into deviant sects." This is what they mean. The essentials of the utmost truth are utterly simple and easy—difficult to encounter, yet easy to accomplish. If one meets a perfected being who points the way, none fail to succeed.*

Ding’an said: *This disciple, by past karmic affinity, has been fortunate to meet you, Master, and receive the Dharma-milk. I humbly beseech your illumination of the essentials of the Golden Elixir.*

The Master said: *Listen carefully now, and I shall expound. The practice of the Elixir lies entirely in seizing the transformations of Heaven and Earth. Take Qian and Kun as the crucible and vessel, the sun and moon as water and fire, yin and yang as the mechanism of transformation, the crow and hare as the medicinal substances. Rely on the celestial pivot’s revolutions, depend on the Dipper’s handle to advance and retreat. Gather qi at the proper time, move the tally according to principle. Advance the fire and retreat the tally, harmonize the Four Images. Pursue the two qi to return them to the Yellow Path, unite the three natures in the Primordial Palace. Return to the root and revert to the origin, restore the mandate. When merit is complete and spirit perfected, the mortal sheds its shell to become an immortal—this is called Elixir Accomplishment.*

Ding’an said: *The transformations of Heaven and Earth seem difficult to seize.*

The Master said: *It is entirely within the single body—what difficulty is there? Heaven and Earth are the physical form; water and fire are essence and qi; yin and yang are body and mind; the crow and hare are nature and emotion. Thus, the physical form serves as the crucible and furnace, essence and qi as water and fire, emotion and nature as the mechanism of transformation, body and mind as the medicinal materials. The sages, fearing that students would have no standard to follow, used Heaven and Earth as metaphors. The human body and the transformations of Heaven and Earth are no different. The two words "body" and "mind" are the medicine, are the fire.*

*Thus, the celestial hun and terrestrial po, the Qian horse and Kun ox, yang lead and yin mercury, Kan man and Li woman, sun crow and moon hare—none lie outside the two words "body" and "mind." The celestial pivot’s revolutions are the celestial mind. The Elixir scriptures say: "If the human mind unites with the celestial mind, the inversion of yin and yang ceases in an instant." They also say: "Observe the Dao through the mind, and the Dao is the mind; observe the mind through the Dao, and the mind is the Dao."*

chunks.original_text: 斗柄推迁者，玄关也。 夫玄关者，至玄至妙之机关也。 今之学者多泥形体，或云眉间，或云脐轮，或云两肾中间，或云脐后肾前，或云膀胱，或云丹田，或云首有九宫为玄关，或指产门为生身处，或指口鼻为玄牝，都皆非也。 但着於形体上，都不是。 亦不可离此身，向外寻求。 诸丹经皆不言，正在何处。 此所以难形笔舌，亦说不得，故曰玄关二字。 所以圣人只书一个中字。 示人此中字，玄关明矣。 所谓中者，非中外之中，亦非四维上下之中，不是在中之中。 释氏云：不思善，不思恶，正於恁么时，那个是自己本来面目。 此禅家之中也。 儒曰：喜怒哀乐未发之谓中。 道教曰：念头不动处谓之中，此道教之中也。 此乃三教只用一个中也。 《易》曰：寂然不动，中之体也； 感而遂通，中之用也。 老子云：致虚极，守静笃，万物并作，吾以观其复。 《易》云：复，见天地之心。 且复卦一阳生於五阴之下。 阴者，静也。 阳者，动也。 静极生动。 只这动处，便是玄关也。 公但向二六时中，举心动念处着工夫，久久玄关自然见也。 若得见玄关，药物火候，抽添运用，乃至脱胎神化，并不出此一窍。 采药者，采身中真铅真汞也。 药生有时。 夫时者，非冬至，非月生，非子时。 师云：炼丹不用寻冬至，身中自有一阳生。 又云：铅到癸生急须采，金逢望远不堪尝。 以此寻身中癸生时，是一阳也，便可下手采之。 二气交合之后，要识持盈，不可太过，望远不堪尝。 进火退符，无以取则，遂一年节候，寒暑往来，以为火符之则。 又以一月盈亏，以明抽添之指。 且如冬至阳生，复卦，十二月； 二阳临卦，正月； 三阳泰卦，二月； 四阳大壮卦，三月； 五阳夬卦，四月； 六阳，纯阳乾卦，阳极阴生，五月； 一阴姤卦，六月； 二阴遁卦，七月； 三阴否卦，八月； 四阴观卦，九月； 五阴剥卦，十月； 纯阴坤卦，阴极阳生，周而复始。 此火符进退之机。 奈何学者执文泥象，以冬至日下手进火，夏至日退符，二八月沐浴，由不知其要也。 圣人见学者错用心志，又以一年节候，促在一月之内，以朔望象冬夏二至，以两弦比二八月，以两日半准一月，以三十日准一年。 学者又着在月上用工夫。 又以月亏盈促在一日，以子午体朔望，以卯酉体二弦。 学者又着在一日上做工夫。 近代真师云：一刻之工夫，自有一年之节候。 又曰：父母未生前，焉有年月日时。 此圣人诱喻学者勿错用心。 奈何泥着之徒，不穷其理，执文泥象，徒尔劳心。 余今直指与公，身中癸生时，便是一阳也； 阳升阴降，便是三阳也。 阴阳分，便是四阳，体二月，如上弦，比卯时，为沐浴，然后进火。 阴阳交，神炁合，六阳也。 阴阳相交，神炁混融之后，要识持盈。 不知止足，前功俱废。 故曰：丹金逢望远不堪尝。 然后退符，象一阴，乃至阴阳分，象三阴，阴阳伏位，宜沐浴，象八月，比下弦，如酉时也。 然后运至六阴，阴极阳生，顷刻之间，一周天也。 公但依而行之，久久工夫渐凝渐结，无质生质，结成圣胎，谓之丹成也。 定庵曰：下手工夫，周天火候之用，已蒙师开发，种种异名不能尽知，望师指示。 师曰：异名者，只是譬喻，无出乎身心二字。 下工之际，凝耳韵，含眼光，缄舌炁，调鼻息，四大不动。
chunks.translated_text:
The Dipper’s handle in its revolutions—this is the Mysterious Pass. The Mysterious Pass is the most profound and wondrous mechanism. Yet many of today’s students cling to physical forms, some claiming it lies between the brows, others at the navel wheel, or between the two kidneys, or behind the navel and before the kidneys, or in the bladder, or in the Cinnabar Field, or in the nine palaces of the head as the Mysterious Pass, or pointing to the birth gate as the place of bodily origin, or to the mouth and nose as the Mysterious Female—all these are mistaken. To fixate on physical form is entirely wrong. Yet one must not seek it outside this body either. The various Elixir scriptures do not specify its location, precisely because it defies description in words or brush. Hence the term "Mysterious Pass." The sages merely inscribed a single character: *zhong* ("center"). Through this *zhong*, the Mysterious Pass becomes clear.

This *zhong* is not the center between inner and outer, nor the center among the four directions or above and below, nor the center within a center. The Buddhists say: "Neither think of good nor think of evil; at just such a moment, what is your original face?" This is the *zhong* of Chan. The Confucians say: "Before joy, anger, sorrow, and pleasure are aroused—this is called *zhong*." The Daoists say: "Where thoughts do not stir—this is called *zhong*." Thus, the Three Teachings employ but a single *zhong*.

The *Book of Changes* states: "Still and unmoving—this is the essence of *zhong*; responsive and penetrating—this is the function of *zhong*." Laozi says: "Attain utmost emptiness, guard profound stillness; as the myriad things arise together, I observe their return." The *Book of Changes* says: "Return reveals the heart of Heaven and Earth." Now, in the *Fu* hexagram, one yang is born beneath five yin. Yin is stillness; yang is movement. When stillness reaches its extreme, movement is born. At this very point of movement lies the Mysterious Pass. Simply apply effort in the moments of thought and action throughout the twelve double-hours. Over time, the Mysterious Pass will naturally appear. Once seen, the medicinal substances, fire phases, withdrawal and addition, and even the transformation of the embryo and spiritual transcendence—none lie beyond this single aperture.

To "gather the medicine" is to gather the true lead and true mercury within the body. The medicine arises at a specific time. This time is not the winter solstice, nor the waxing moon, nor the midnight hour. The master says: "In refining the Elixir, there is no need to seek the winter solstice; within the body, a yang naturally arises." He also says: "When lead reaches *gui*-birth, swiftly gather it; when gold meets the full moon, it is no longer fit to taste." Thus, seek the moment of *gui*-birth within the body—this is the arising of one yang, the time to begin gathering.

After the union of the two qi, one must recognize how to maintain fullness and avoid excess. "When gold meets the full moon, it is no longer fit to taste." Advancing the fire and withdrawing the tally lack clear standards, so the yearly cycle of seasons—cold and heat coming and going—serves as the model for the fire tally. The waxing and waning of the moon also illustrate the principles of withdrawal and addition. For example: at the winter solstice, yang is born—the *Fu* hexagram, twelfth month; two yangs—the *Lin* hexagram, first month; three yangs—the *Tai* hexagram, second month; four yangs—the *Dazhuang* hexagram, third month; five yangs—the *Guai* hexagram, fourth month; six yangs—the pure yang *Qian* hexagram, where yang reaches its extreme and yin is born, fifth month; one yin—the *Gou* hexagram, sixth month; two yins—the *Dun* hexagram, seventh month; three yins—the *Pi* hexagram, eighth month; four yins—the *Guan* hexagram, ninth month; five yins—the *Bo* hexagram, tenth month; pure yin—the *Kun* hexagram, where yin reaches its extreme and yang is born, returning to the beginning. This is the mechanism of advancing and withdrawing the fire tally.

Alas, students cling to texts and adhere to images, beginning the fire advance at the winter solstice, withdrawing the tally at the summer solstice, and bathing in the second and eighth months, unaware of the essentials. Seeing students misdirect their efforts, the sages compressed the yearly cycle into a single month, using the new and full moons to represent the winter and summer solstices, the two quarters to represent the second and eighth months, two and a half days to represent a month, and thirty days to represent a year. Yet students then fixated on the moon for their practice. The sages further compressed the moon’s waxing and waning into a single day, using midnight and noon to represent the new and full moons, and dawn and dusk to represent the two quarters. Students then fixated on a single day for their practice.

Masters of recent times have said: "Within a single moment of effort lies a year’s cycle of seasons." They also said: "Before father and mother were born, where were the years, months, days, and hours?" This is how the sages guided students to avoid misdirecting their efforts. Alas, those who cling to forms do not fathom the principle, adhering to texts and images, vainly exhausting their minds.

I now directly point this out to you: the moment of *gui*-birth within the body is the arising of one yang. When yang ascends and yin descends, this is three yangs. When yin and yang separate, this is four yangs—corresponding to the second month, like the waxing moon, akin to the *mao* hour, the time for bathing, then advancing the fire. When yin and yang unite and spirit and qi merge, this is six yangs. After yin and yang unite and spirit and qi blend, one must recognize how to maintain fullness. Without knowing when to stop, all previous efforts are wasted. Hence it is said: "When elixir gold meets the full moon, it is no longer fit to taste." Then withdraw the tally, corresponding to one yin, and when yin and yang separate, this is three yins—yin and yang in their hidden positions, the time for bathing, corresponding to the eighth month, like the waning moon, akin to the *you* hour. Then proceed to six yins, where yin reaches its extreme and yang is born—in an instant, a single celestial revolution is complete.

Simply follow this practice. Over time, effort will gradually congeal and solidify, transforming the formless into form, coalescing into the sacred embryo, called the completion of the Elixir.

Ding’an said: "The initial effort and the application of the celestial revolution’s fire phases have been revealed by the master, yet the various alternate names remain unclear. I hope the master will clarify."

The master said: "Alternate names are merely metaphors, all contained within the two words 'body' and 'mind.' At the outset of practice, concentrate the ear’s resonance, contain the eye’s light, seal the tongue’s qi, and regulate the nose’s breath—let the four great elements remain unmoving."

The celestial pivot’s revolutions are the celestial mind. The Elixir scriptures say: "If the human mind unites with the celestial mind, the inversion of yin and yang ceases in an instant." They also say: "Observe the Dao through the mind, and the Dao is the mind; observe the mind through the Dao, and the mind is the Dao."*
